article.title: Polynomials, sign patterns and Descartes' rule of signs

multiple_choice_question.text: The classical Descartes\' rule of signs states that a real polynomial P(x, a) := x<sup>d</sup>+a<sub>d−1</sub>x<sup>d−1</sup>+⋅ ⋅ ⋅+a<sub>0</sub> has *at most* how many positive roots?
choices: b) The number of sign changes in the sequence of its coefficients (c)
c) The number of sign preservations in the sequence of its coefficients (p)

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Z<sub>2</sub> x Z<sub>2</sub>-action represent in the context of sign patterns and admissible pairs for real polynomials?
choices: a) It changes the degree of the polynomial.
b) It defines four couples (sign pattern, admissible pair) that are either all realizable or all non-realizable.
c) It calculates the exact number of positive and negative roots of a given polynomial.
d) It describes the relationship between the coefficients and the roots of a polynomial.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the paper, what does the variable κ represent in Lemma 1, which discusses the realizability of specific sign patterns with the admissible pair (0, d-2)?
choices: a) The number of positive roots of the polynomial.
b) The number of negative roots of the polynomial.
c) A value calculated from the number of pluses and minuses in the sign pattern.
d) The degree of the polynomial.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Lemma 3, for a polynomial in the set S¯ (subset of polynomials with signs of coefficients defined by σ<sub>0</sub> and realizing the pair (1,8)), which coefficient(s) must be equal to zero?
choices: b) a<sub>9</sub>, a<sub>8</sub>, a<sub>7</sub>, a<sub>4</sub>, a<sub>3</sub>, a<sub>2</sub>
